Graphics are nice, but can't see it worth for 9.99 , i asked for a refund after 30 mins of play it was just that bad. reviewText:
Terrible game.
Barely any crafting, So bad in fact that it lists the same recipes multiple times in teh same single list of the handful of craftable items.
Players are immediately able to fight one another as soon as you take a few steps away from the start area, which means many just camp the start area.  So (at least when i played) i logged in, walked a little and got ganked.  Logged in again ran away real fast, then found a dungeon got a couple things, died, ported back to start area, where i got ganked again losing my stuff i just found.
That aside...
I was in the starting area looking at the very very dark world holding my staff, and the frame rate is so low that i thought the staff that everyone wields was a melee weapon.  After a while it started shooting the firebolt everyone has.
The graphics are not terrible, but they're not good, the gameplay is quite bad, the framerate is terrible, the areas are very small.
It's just not good.
If this was early access it would be worth 50 cents, but as a final version.. save yourself the disk space.

reviewText:
GUIDE: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=665700906


I recommend this game:


The point of this game is to craft gear, claim a tower, pvp, and storm the Dungeon in the middle. My experience with the frame rate has been consistantly near 40-60 fps.

When you first start, there is unfortunately no tutorial yet, so you are kind of confused on what to do. This makes it hard to progres through the game as you have to ask around, look up information, or play by trial and error style. There are two control lists though: One is in the Esc menu when you bring it up, the other is in the Command List button that appears after booting up the game and the servers appear. Unfortunately, these control lists still lack some information on how to progress (Example: eating is right clicking a food item, which starts regenerating your health).


Crafting:
Crafting seems simple and basic at first due to you only having access to tier 1 items which give small amounts of health, defense, and intellect. However, once a tower is claimed and you construct a workshop, you gain access to higher tier items to craft (the same goes for two of the other rooms that you can build for your tower). The crafting system actually works like it is supposed to, every item you craft will be placed in your inventory and be fully operational immediately.
The gear you craft is essential to survival, as tougher mobs/experienced players in the game will punish you for not going in with the proper armor and weapons. Also, the better armor and health you have, the more health you regenerate. Currently, only two pieces of armor give any cosmetical change when equipped, and the staff you equip will also change its appearance based on what tier it is.

Towers:
The towers function as temporary player homes, with large control stones out in front of each one. If there is a stream of light connecting it to the lantern, then you have to attack the stone until it is unclaimed before you can proceed to claim it, unless it is your tower. Currently, there are no tower defenses besides the beefy control stone.
The second purpose of the tower, is to acquire better equipment and items. When you own a tower, you can craft four rooms and each provide its own benefits. The bedroom provides a respawn point other than the safe area, the laboratory allows the crafting of health potions, and the workshop allows you to craft more powerful equipment. The kitchen is currently pointless right now, as it provides 1 additional food recipe that isn't that useful besides getting rid of a certain material needed. Towards the bottom of the tower is also a storage chest that comes free of charge, where you can safely put away your items and not worry about losing one of them from dying.
If your tower is unclaimed, you lose all of these rooms, so guard your tower carefully while you are on! Your storage chest will most likely be emptied by the player that unclaimed it, then stocked with his or her own items.

PVP:
Pvp is a part of the game, something that was beaten into me the first time I played it. Skirmishes between low to no geared players are common, but many of the new players will typically leave the more heavily armored player alone, or the helpful players. You can group up with other players, but unfortunately friendly fire is still a thing right now, so you must be careful with aiming.
Unfortunately at the moment (this will change depending on patches) Pvp between more powerful players is unheard of. There is either no more than one higher geared player on, or they don't bother even fighting because Damage and Defense iare still buggy and makes these higher geared players do chip damage to each other (this is likely to change).


PVE (and the Dungeon):
Pve is rough at first, with other players that might interfere with your grinding, and being ungeared leads to a swift death at the hands of both players and mobs. However, these mobs on the outside become easier the more or better gear you have. The ungeared players will still most likely target you unless you have tier 2-3 gear, as you can still be vulnerable to a gank. Often times, PvE can be frustrating, as you have to rely on random drops from mobs and your area being empty of hostile players while you harvest. There are two types of mobs in the game: normal and elite. Elite variants of the mobs are larger, and characterized by a glowing red aura, more damage, and more health. Elites have a chance of dropping rare materials.
The Dungeon is the large center tower in the middle of the map, and you will frequently see new players die in there from the chat log. The Dungeon is meant to be difficult, as I only went in there AFTER I had a full tier 1 armor set equipped and even then I died a lot. The mobs in there usually have far more health than anything outside, and deal more damage (specifically, one rare mob that spawns)  which makes them tear apart the unprepared in seconds. For those wanting better gear, you have to go through it though. Only in the Dungeon can you find the rare materials you need to craft higher tier gear reliably, though be prepared to fight for it.



Final Thoughts:
I honestly like this game (as you can probably tell by how many hours I've played), even though after its release it is still very buggy. However, the core mechanics still work, and Digital Homicide is very committed to making this game better, as shown by their forum posts/responses, and overall interactions (in game or email). While they may not have a good reputation, and you may not like any of there games, this is the one that you should support and give constructive feedback on. The game may have had an early ending to its Early Access, but that doesn't mean the game isn't being worked on as you can tell by the patches STILL BEING PUT OUT.

My recommendation: Give the game a shot, and try it for a while. If you get stuck, ask around, or check out the guide/forums for answers. Honestly, this game deserves your consideration, no matter how many people with less than an hour of game time say so in their reviews. I approached this game thinking I wouldn't have a fun time.

I was mistaken, and I do not regret this purchase at all.

There are some things that needs to be tuned and some things that needs to be implemented. Like a tutorial and a more clear goal.

The game also needs to fix the pvp part in some way. The only feeling i got from playing was to not interact with unknown players, at all. Since a random guy might kill you which makes you drop a random material/item from your inventory. And that is irritating as ♥♥♥♥ if you are losing a rare material.
I might try this game later on and if i feel like it improved i will change my review.

reviewText:
The only game DHS actually put some effort into. I would recomment it for one reason and one reason only, and that is its fun.

I got this game as more as a joke, to add to my DHS collection. But after playing it with my friend for hours, it has it's own charm to the game.
While it may be laggy and glitchy and there's no real point to the game, we still had fun exploring, finding glitches, messing around, and meeting new people. We would make friends with people, and enemies. You can destroy people's towers and steal all of their stuff. Super fun in my opinion.

The devs do actually update and fix the game. I even got to talk to James, one of the devs, he came on the server and accounced he was about to update to fix bugs with the dungeons.

The community is very welcoming. When I first got on the game for the first time, a very friendly player was there to teach me how to play. While this was nice, they COULD add somewhat of a tutorial.

At the end of the day, it was well-worth the 15 bucks, I would HIGHLY recomment play with a friend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think it's an okay game. I've only played half an hour and I enjoyed it. The graphics are nice, there seems to be lots to explore and a lot of enemies, such as the one-eyed wizard or the were-rat. Although some enemies do not have death animations, it is satisfying to see them fall slowly through the floor, like in an old school game where the bosses would explode and fall down slowly. Digital Homicide does not have the greatest reputation, but this game can become something really fun to play if they keep working on it. I just hope that AllShamNoWow doesn't be too hard on the game.

So in the end, It's aight and I recommend it!
voteText: 71 of 286 people (25%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With 11 hours of gameplay I think I'll write a review, as the other reviews didn't play long enough to experience it.

Starting out you are kind of bewildered at what to do or where to go, you will see a long walk way and two wasp with a staircase leading up into what looks like a skull this is the dungeon entrance. If you continue around the entrance's in a circle you will see other long walk ways which lead to safe zones, if you continue down the smaller paths you will end up going down a  deadend path  with a tower at the end of it. These towers are player owned houses which are contested and can be attacked and claimed. The towers also unlock another portion of the game which allow you to build crafting stations to advance into tier 2 items.

The game itself has a great concept it just needs more of what it already has.

The graphics are nice it all looks well polished and the dark graphics are easy on the eyes.

The game is a grindfest but if you're like myself and have 2000+ hours on diablo 3 you fit in perfect.

It's a easy game to run so lower end systems shouldn't have a problem however FPS randomly drops for a few seconds when phasing into a new zone.

The user interface is simple and not to confusing I would like to see health numbers and damage numbers added in the future.

The dept of game is very shallow at the moment but it is also very early in the development I see it having a lot of potential and Digital homicide hit the nail on the head with this release.

All in all I give the game a 8/10 only because I crafted end tier items with only 6 hours of play time. With all that being said I see the game worth the  $10 people have been complaining about  there is more then $10 in development here.
